questions.text: A 28 year old male patient presented with genital ulcer since 1 week. On examination, there was painless, single, well defined indurated ulcer as shown in the image. There was painless inguinal lymph node enlargement. There was a history of unprotected intercourse one month back. What will be the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The classic primary syphilis presentation is a solitary non-tender genital chancre in response to invasion by the T. pallidum.

The ulcer is well defined indurated hard (button like) chancre with shotty painless lymphadenopathy.

Incubation period - 9-90 days

Option A: Herpes progenitalis

Herpes genitalis is among the most common sexually transmitted infections. It is caused by the herpes simplex virus type 1 and 2

Multiple clear fluid filled vesicles rupture to form superficial erosions with polycyclic margins associated with pain. It can lead to recurrent lesions.

Treatment with tab. Acyclovir 400 mg TDS for 7 days.

Option B: Chancroid

Chancroid is caused by the gram-negative bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi (H. ducreyi). It is characterized by painful genital ulcers and painful swollen lymph glands in the inguinal area (bubo). A Gram stain shows 'school of fish appearance'.

Option D: Lymphogranuloma venereum is an ulcerative sexually transmitted infection of the genital area caused by Chlamydia trachomatis L1, L2, and L3

lymphogranuloma venereum has three stages of infection:

  • Primary stage characterized by the development of painless genital ulcer or papules.
  • Secondary stage with the development of unilateral or bilateral tender inguinal and/or femoral lymphadenopathy (also called buboes).
  • Late stage with strictures, fibrosis, and fistulae of the anogenital area.

Key Takeaway:

Primary Syphilis Ulcer

  • Single
  • Indurated
  • Non Tender & Non Bleeding
  • Painless Lymphadenopathy

questions.text: A 34-year-old truck driver presented with skin lesions as shown in the image since 1 month ago. There was a history of multiple sex partners. What will be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Syphilis is a systemic, bacterial infection caused by the spirochete Treponema pallidum.

Primary syphilis appears 10 to 90 days after exposure to the infection and comprises a painless, indurated ulcer button like hard chancre at the site of inoculation with the T. pallidum. Regional lymphadenopathy is common and consists of rubbery lymph nodes.

Secondary syphilis appears 2 to 8 weeks after the disappearance of the chancre and has multiple systemic manifestations that can involve any system and body part. The cutaneous manifestations are also varied:

  • condyloma lata (MOST INFECTIOUS LESIONS OF SECONDARY SYPHILIS)
  • moth eaten alopecia
  • mucous patches
  • palmoplantar hyperpigmented macules or scaly papules or
  • truncal rash - macular/maculo papular/papular
  • papulosquamous rash

Primary and secondary syphilis treatment - Inj. Benzathine penicillin 2.4 MU single dose

Untreated primary or secondary syphilis is followed by an early latent phase (one year or less later on) or late latent phase (over one year) and is characterized by positive serologic tests but negative clinical manifestations.

Tertiary syphilis is late symptomatic syphilis that can manifest months or years after the initial infection as cardiovascular syphilis (an aortic aneurysm, aortic valvulopathy), neurosyphilis (meningitis, hemiplegia, stroke, aphasia, seizures, tabes dorsalis), or gummatous syphilis.

Option A: HFMD Caused by Coxsackie Virus Involves Face with Palm & Soles.

Option C: Scabies A Parasitic infection caused by sarcoptes Scabiei affects Interdigital area then whole body sparing face.

Option D: Psoriasis is a papulosquamous disorder that primarily affects extensor surfaces.

Key Takeaway:

Secondary syphilis lesions:

  • condyloma lata (MOST INFECTIOUS LESIONS OF SECONDARY SYPHILIS)
  • moth eaten alopecia,
  • mucous patches
  • palmoplantar hyperpigmented macules
  • papulosquamous rash

questions.text: An adult male with multiple sexual partners has a painless genital ulcer. What is the next IOC?
questions.solution:
Male patient with multiple sexual partners having painless genital ulcers suggest primary syphilis. Dark ground illumination is IOC for Primary syphilis.

Blood investigations are negative in primary syphilis.

Option B: Gram stain is useful for diagnosis of chancroid. It shows School of fish appearance

Option C: HSV 2 Ab is useful for herpes genitalis

Option D: Giemsa stain is useful for donovanosis. It shows Macrophages with closed safety pin appearance called 'donovan body'.

Key Takeaway:

IOC in Primary syphilis is Dark Ground Microscopy which reveals thin slender bacteria.

questions.text: Kassowitz law is related with
questions.solution:
Congenital syphilis laws:

KASSOWITZ LAW - If a woman with untreated syphilis has a series of pregnancies, the likelihood of infection of the fetus in later pregnancies becomes less.

COLLE'S LAW - A newborn child affected with congenital syphilis, even though it may have symptoms in the mouth, never causes ulceration of the breast which it sucks, if it is the mother who suckles it, though continuing capable of infecting a strange nurse.

PROFETA'S LAW - At birth, an infected infant may appear healthy and may not develop signs till it is some weeks old, but in other cases, signs are present at birth

Other Option: Kassowitz Law is Related to Abortion so not related with other types of Syphilis.

Key Takeaway:

KASSOWITZ LAW - If a woman with untreated syphilis has a series of pregnancies, the likelihood of infection of the fetus in later pregnancies becomes less as seen in congenital Syphilis.

questions.text: A 30 year old male diagnosed with secondary syphilis treated with Inj. Benzathine penicillin. Six hours after the penicillin dose, the patient develops fever, chills, flushing, myalgias, headache, and tachycardia. He was diagnosed as having a Jarisch Herxheimer reaction. All of the following cytokines are responsible except?
questions.solution:
Interferon Gamma Is not involved in Pathophysiology of Jarisch Herxheimer Reaction. (Option D)

In secondary syphilis, Inj. Benzathine penicillin leads to lysis of T. pallidum and release of endotoxin and lipoproteins, Cytokine IL-6, IL-8 and TNF-α release. (Option A, B & C) This leads to fever, chills, rigor, nausea, tachycardia, hypotension, flushing, and myalgia. Treatment is Conservative.

Key Takeaway:

Jarisch Herxheimer Reaction

  • Fever, Chills, Rigor, Tachycardia & Hypotension
  • Due to IL6 , IL8 & TNF alpha on administration of Inj. Benzathine Penicillin
  • Benign Condition

Reference: Butler T. The Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction after antibiotic treatment of spirochetal infections: a review of recent cases and our understanding of pathogenesis. The American Journal of tropical medicine and hygiene. 2017 Jan 1;96(1):46.

questions.text: Bubo is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Bubo - A characteristic painful swelling of inguinal nodes - Most Common presentation of LGV in men.

Option B: HSV Present with painful but not Suppurative lymph node Enlargement.

Option C: Syphilis - Painless swelling of inguinal Lymph Node.

Option D: Do NO vanosis - NO lymph node involvement, Pseudobubo

Key Takeaway:

Bubo - A characteristic painful Suppurative swelling of inguinal nodes is Most Common presentation of LGV in men.

questions.text: A patient came to the OPD with complaints of pain in his genital area. On examination, there was a painful coalescing vesicle, associated with painful lymphadenopathy. What could be the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Herpes genitalis is among the most common sexually transmitted infections. It is caused by the herpes simplex virus type 1 and 2.

Multiple clear fluid filled vesicles rupture to form superficial erosions with polycyclic margins associated with pain.

It can lead to recurrent lesions.

Treatment with tab. Acyclovir 400 mg TDS for 7 days.

Option B: Molluscum contagiosum are asymptomatic skin colored to white papules caused by pox virus.

Option C: HPV virus causes asymptomatic verrucous growth.

Option D: Varicella zoster causes chickenpox which Present with Rose petal Pleomorphic Rash.

Key Takeaway:

Herpes Genitalis:

  • Caused By HSV 1&2
  • Multiple clear fluid filled vesicles rupture to form superficial erosions with polycyclic margins associated with pain.
  • It can lead to recurrent lesions.
  • Tzanck smear: Multinucleated Giant Cells
  • Rx: tab. Acyclovir 400 mg TDS for 7 days.

questions.text: A college student came with painful grouped vesicles over genitalia. What will be the next investigation you want to perform & what will be the finding?
questions.solution:
Herpes genitalis presents as painful grouped vesicles over genitals. For this, Tzanck smear would be the next investigation which shows tzanck cells and multinucleated giant cells.

Option B: In chancroid, gram staining is done which shows gram positive organism in 'school of fish' pattern

Option C: In leprosy, SSS (SLit skin smear) shows Acid fast bacilli

Option D: Molluscum contagiosum biopsy shows henderson patterson bodies.

Key Takeaway:

Herpes Genitalis:

  • Caused By HSV 1&2
  • Multiple clear fluid filled vesicles rupture to form superficial erosions with polycyclic margins associated with pain.
  • It can lead to recurrent lesions.
  • Tzanck smear: Multinucleated Giant Cells
  • Rx: tab. Acyclovir 400 mg TDS for 7 days.

questions.text: A 35 year old male presented with painful genital lesions for 2 days. History of fluid filled lesions present. There were 3 episodes of similar lesion in the past. On examination there were multiple superficial erosions with polycyclic margin over glans. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Herpes progenitalis

Herpes genitalis is among the most common sexually transmitted infections. It is caused by the herpes simplex virus type 1 and 2.

Multiple clear fluid filled vesicles rupture to form superficial erosions with polycyclic margins associated with pain.

It can lead to recurrent lesions.

Treatment with tab. Acyclovir 400 mg TDS for 7 days.

Option A: Chancroid

Chancroid is caused by the gram-negative bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi (H. ducreyi). It is characterized by painful genital ulcers and painful swollen lymph glands in the inguinal area (bubo). A Gram stain shows 'school of fish appearance'.

Option B: Lymphogranuloma venereum is an ulcerative sexually transmitted infection of the genital area caused by Chlamydia trachomatis L1 , L2, and L3

Characteristically, LGV has three stages of infection:

  • Primary stage characterized by the development of painless genital ulcer or papules.
  • Secondary stage with the development of unilateral or bilateral tender inguinal and/or femoral lymphadenopathy (also called buboes).
  • Late stage with strictures, fibrosis, and fistulae of the anogenital area.

Option C: Primary syphilis

The classic primary syphilis presentation is a solitary non-tender genital chancre in response to invasion by the T. pallidum. The ulcer is well defined indurated hard (button like) chancre with shotty lymphadenopathy.

Key Takeaway:

Herpes Genitalis:

  • Caused By HSV 1&2
  • Multiple clear fluid filled vesicles rupture to form superficial erosions with polycyclic margins associated with pain.
  • It can lead to recurrent lesions.
  • Tzanck smear: Multinucleated Giant Cells
  • Rx: tab. Acyclovir 400 mg TDS for 7 days.

questions.text: True regarding chancroids except?
questions.solution:
Chancroid:

Causative org- Haemophilus ducreyi

Painful, soft(non indurated) Bleeding ulcer (Option B & C)

Painful suppurative Lymph Node - 'Bubo'

Gram stain - Gram negative bacteria in 'school of fish appearance' (Option A)

Option D: Groove sign is seen in LGV so It's An Incorrect Option.

Key Takeaway:

Chancroid

  • Caused by H. Ducreyi
  • Painful soft Bleeding Ulcer
  • Painful Suppurative Lymphadenopathy
  • School of Fish Appearance on gram stain.

questions.text: A 30 year old male presented with urethral discharge. Gram stain image shown below. Which of the following could be the most likely organism?
questions.solution:
Gonorrhea is caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

Male patients present with thick, profuse, purulent urethral discharge.

In Female patients, endocervix is the site of primary infection. It can lead to cervicitis, salpingitis and PID.

Gram Stain: Gram shows intracellular gram negative diplococci.

Diagnosis: Culture is the gold standard method for diagnosis.

Management: Inj. Ceftriaxone 250mg im stat + T. Azithro 1g stat is given for treatment.

Option A:

Etiology: Caused by Trichomonas vaginalis

Symptoms:

Profuse, itchy vaginal discharge

Greenish-yellow, frothy vaginal discharge

Strawberry cervix (a condition where the cervix appears red and spotted)

Management:

Syndromic management with Kit-2: Secnidazole 2g and Fluconazole 150 mg

Option C:

Chlamydia Trachomatis causes PID, Reactive Arthritis but doesn't Present like diplococci.

Option D: Gardenella Vaginalis causes Bacterial Vaginosis which is not Inflammatory condition.

Key Takeaway:

Gonococcal Urethritis:

  • Diffuse, yellowish discharge with urinary complaints and constitutional symptoms
  • Intracellular Diplococci on Microscopy
  • Rx: Inj. Ceftriaxone 250mg im stat + T. Azithro 1g stat.

questions.text: A male patient presenting with complaints of burning micturition and urethral discharge after 1 week of unprotected intercourse. Identify the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Urethritis:

  • Gonococcal - Diffuse, yellowish discharge with urinary complaints and constitutional symptoms
  • Nongonococcal - Scanty, watery discharge without urinary complaints

Gonococcal urethritis

Causative organism - Neisseria gonorrhoeae

Incubation period - 1-14 days

Non gonococcal urethritis:

Chlamydia trachomatis

Mycoplasma

Ureaplasma urealyticum

Trichomonas vaginalis

Almost all urethritis patients have penile discharge, gonococcal urethritis can easily be distinguished from NGU by looking for gram-negative diplococci on a gram stain. If intracellular diplococci are identified, the urethritis is gonococcal; if no diplococci are identified, the diagnosis is classified as NGU.

For non gonococcal urethritis NAAT Nucleic acid amplification test is useful.

Option A: ECOli Causes Epididymo Orchitis.

Option C: Ureaplasma causes Nongonococcal urethritis which Present with Scanty, watery discharge without urinary complaints.

Option D: Trichomonas causes Nongonococcal urethritis which Present with Scanty, watery discharge without urinary complaints.

Key Takeaway:

Gonococcal Urethritis:

  • Diffuse, yellowish discharge with urinary complaints and constitutional symptoms
  • Intracellular Diplococci on Microscopy

questions.text:
Correct answer for STI kit color is___

1 - urethritis
2 - Vaginal discharge
3 - Non herpetic genital ulcers
4 - Lower abdominal pain

a - green
b - yellow
c - gray
d - blue
questions.solution:
See Kit table below

Key Takeaway:

Reference: STI Operational Guidelines - NACO

questions.text: A patient presents with lesions on inner thighs and peri anal region. They are nodular, 4-6 mm in size. The histopathological appearance is shown in the image. The diagnosis is____
questions.solution:
The image is showing histology of molluscum contagiosum.

Cup shaped lesion with inverted lobules of hyperplastic squamous epithelium which expand into the underlying dermis.

Henderson-Paterson or molluscum bodies are large (up to 35 microns) intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusion bodies. At the granular layer, the bodies become increasingly hematoxyphilic and occupy the entire cell.

Option A: Trichodysplasia spinulosa is a rare inherited skin condition characterized by the development of numerous, small, spiny hair follicles. These spiky hairs are often present from birth or appear during childhood.

Option B: Condylomata acuminata caused by HPV

Two types of HPV virus

  • Low risk - 6,11
  • High risk - 16,18

Site:

  • In male - frenulum, sulcus
  • In female - posterior fourchette

Giant condyloma acuminata is known as Buschke lowenstein tumor, which has more chance of malignancy

Treatment: Podophyllin toxin, Imiquimod, Cryotherapy, Radiofrequency fulguration

Option C: Donovanosis, also known as granuloma inguinale, is a chronic bacterial infection that affects the genitals and surrounding areas. It is caused by the bacterium Klebsiella granulomatis.

Key Takeaway:

Molluscum Contagiosum:

  • Henderson Patterson Bodies
  • Asymptomatic Umbilicated Papules

questions.text: A male presented with multiple warty lesions around anus. The lesions are gradually increasing. On examination they are soft and sessile and didn't bleed on touch. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Genital warts are also known as condyloma acuminata

Condylomata acuminata caused by HPV

Two types of HPV virus

  • Low risk - 6,11
  • High risk - 16,18

Site:

  • In male - frenulum, sulcus
  • In female - posterior fourchette

Giant condyloma acuminata is known as Buschke lowenstein tumor, which has more chance of malignancy

Treatment: Podophyllin toxin, Imiquimod, Cryotherapy, Radiofrequency fulguration

Option A: Condyloma lata is seen in secondary syphilis. Greyish white flat plaque having moist oozy surface and they are most infectious lesion of secondary syphilis.

Option C: Bowens disease is SCC in situ. Usually seen on the lower limb as a red shiny plaque.

Option D: Hemorrhoids are swollen veins in rectum.

Key takeaway:

HPV Causes Condyloma Acuminata:

  • For malignant transformation:
    1. E6 protein: (-) P53 gene.
    2. E7 protein: (-) RB gene.
  • For HPV vaccines: L1 capsid protein.
  • For viral replications: E1 & E2.
  • M/C HPV causing condyloma Acuminata: HPV 6 & 11

questions.text: Which of the following strains of HPV are more commonly associated with cervical carcinoma.
questions.solution:
Infection by the human papillomavirus (HPV) is the most important risk factor for cervical cancer

HPVs can be grouped to high-risk and low-risk HPV types.

High-risk HPV types include types 16, 18

Low-risk HPV types include types 6, 11.

HPV & Cervical Carcinoma:

  • For malignant transformation:
    1. E6 protein: (-) P53 gene.
    2. E7 protein: (-) RB gene.
  • For HPV vaccines: L1 capsid protein.
  • For viral replications: E1 & E2.
  • M/C HPV causing carcinoma cervix: HPV 16.
  • Most specific for carcinoma cervix: HPV 18.

Key takeaway:

HPV:

  • For malignant transformation:
    1. E6 protein: (-) P53 gene.
    2. E7 protein: (-) RB gene.
  • For HPV vaccines: L1 capsid protein.
  • For viral replications: E1 & E2.
  • M/C HPV causing carcinoma cervix: HPV 16.
  • Most specific for carcinoma cervix: HPV 18.

questions.text: Treatment of genital warts in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Papules with warty surface around genitals which is known as genital warts/Condyloma acuminata

Condylomata acuminata caused by HPV

Two types of HPV virus

  • Low risk - 6,11
  • High risk - 16,18

Treatment:

Podophyllin toxin, Imiquimod, Cryotherapy, Radiofrequency fulguration

In Pregnancy- Cryotherapy. TCA (Trichloroacetic acid)

Option B: Electrocautery is not preferred in pregnancy.

Option C: Radiofrequency fulguration is CI in Pregnancy due to teratogenicity.

Option D: Surgical Excision is not primary modality of management

Key Takeaway:

Genital Warts in Pregnancy is Managed with Cryotherapy.

questions.text: Amsel's criteria does not include______
questions.solution:
Vaginal Ph > 4.5 is Correct So Option C is n't in Amstel criteria

Bacterial vaginosis is diagnosed by the presence of 3 out of 4 Amsel criteria

  1. Thin, homogenous or White adherent vaginal discharge (Option A)
  2. Vaginal pH greater than 4.5 (i.e. greater than normal)(Option C)
  3. Positive whiff test (fishy amine odor when 10 percent potassium hydroxide solution is added) (Option B)
  4. At least 20 percent clue cells (vaginal epithelial cells with borders obscured by adherent coccobacilli on wet-mount. (Option D)

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: A female presents with profuse itchy vaginal discharge and has a strawberry cervix on examination. Which of the following drugs is used in the treatment?
questions.solution:
CDC guideline for Trichomoniasis:

Option A: Tetracycline is used in lower abdominal pain syndrome.

Option C: Acyclovir is used in herpes infection.

Option D: Azithromycin is used in Bubo Management.

Key Takeaway:

Trichomoniasis is Treated with Metronidazole 500 mg orally twice a day for 7 days.

questions.text: Which of the following infections requires male partner treatment?
questions.solution:
Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted disease which requires treatment of all partners.

Option A: Candida infection can occur in diabetes, immunocompromised patients. Thus, it does not always require partner treatment.

Option C: Bacterial vaginosis is not STD.

Option D: Herpes progenitalis has a tendency to recur without exposure. So, it is not always preceded by exposure.

Key Takeaway:

No Partner Treatment done:

  • Candida
  • Bacterial Vaginosis
  • Herpes

questions.text: A 38-year-old man who has sex with men (MSM) presents with chronic genital swelling as shown in the image. He reports a painless genital ulcer a few months ago that resolved spontaneously, followed by tender inguinal lymphadenopathy, which later ruptured. What is the most likely underlying etiology?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical picture and history are classic for Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV)—a sexually transmitted infection caused by Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1–L3. It typically presents with a painless genital ulcer, followed weeks later by painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (bubo) that may rupture.

Chronic lymphatic obstruction can lead to genital elephantiasis, seen here as saxophone penis.

Explanation of Other Options:

Donovanosis (Option B):

  • Caused by Klebsiella granulomatis
  • Painless, beefy-red ulcers that bleed easily
  • Lymphadenopathy and lymphatic obstruction are not features, so genital elephantiasis is not typically seen

Secondary syphilis (Option C):

  • Caused by Treponema pallidum
  • Presents with mucocutaneous rash, condyloma lata, and generalized, non-tender lymphadenopathy
  • It lacks bubo formation or chronic genital swelling, which are characteristic of LGV

Filariasis (Option D):

  • Caused by Wuchereria bancrofti, leads to chronic lymphatic obstruction and genital elephantiasis, but not preceded by genital ulcer or buboes
  • It is a systemic parasitic disease, not sexually transmitted
